body: Nice.

@leventov The issue is that when sketches are empty, the AggregateCombiner.reset() within `SketchAggregatorFactory` does not clear out the combined union object. As a result, this would have the combined value from a previous merge and this stale value would be used as the combined value for the present set of rows. I'm raising a PR shortly for fixing this.
@a2l007 thank you for digging into the problem!
thanks for documenting this, so informative .
Source is viewable now. Example from before: https://coveralls.io/jobs/52320583/source_files/154937110

This is a somewhat duplicate of #8177, but maybe still worth going ahead and doing since the other is tied up in the curator issue.

After #7998 and #8306 (which was just merged and the cause of your conflicts), `LICENSE.BINARY` and `NOTICE.BINARY` are both autogenerated from the contents of `licenses.yaml` at the root of the project. #8367 will add instructions to the PR template indicating that this should be done if dependency versions are bumped, but it is not merged yet.

Could you please fix conflicts update the zookeeper entry 'version' and 'notice' text in [licenses.yaml](https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/blob/master/licenses.yaml#L1453)? 

For the notice, it looks like changing to:

```
Apache ZooKeeper
Copyright 2009-2019 The Apache Software Foundation
```

[should be sufficient](https://github.com/apache/zookeeper/blob/4c25d480e66aadd371de8bd2fd8da255ac140bcf/NOTICE.txt).

@gianm I had looked into how to make a test for this, for unit testing, I initially tried setting up a `toolChest.mergeResults` merging test (like how TopNBenchmark merges queryable indices) using the replication case described in https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/8348, but that doesn't have the JSON serde step and I'm not sure how I would setup the test to do so.

An integration test could be made to specifically test this, but the test would require two historicals, and the integration test environment in travis is already somewhat resource constrained (it also feels a little overkill to me, a lighter weight test seems more ideal)

I could make a unit test that just tests DimValHolder type conversion, but that doesn't really test the original bug situation.

Any thoughts?
Thanks @ccaominh and @jihoonson for review !
The code looks good to me ðŸ‘ I am confused about the coverage decrease this PR does not change any java files

@clintropolis  @jihoonson  Hiï¼Œwhy nobody try to deal with this PR?
@clintropolis I've updated my PR.

Hey @sekingme,

Could you add/update unit tests covering the behaviour this patch fixes please?
@leventov I will, thanks for merging!
For context, #7329 could be used to test `AggregatorCombiner.reset()` in all aggregators
It might make the analysis happen faster at least because we can run only error inspection checks, but not warnings.
How did you fix this issue? Can you share the specific memory configs.? I am also facing similar issue
@QiuMM It would be great if we could push this in 0.16.0 as we're planning to use this feature once it is available. Would it be possible for you to finish this up at your earliest convenience?

> How did you fix this issue? Can you share the specific memory configs.? I am also facing similar issue

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/177816/63531504-845c1100-c4bd-11e9-9b74-60dc7cc807e6.png)

I am sorry that this simple `README.md` change has such grave coverage implications
haven't looked at the discussion here but https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/7824 might be related

> because we can run only error inspection checks, but not warnings.

is it not possible to adjust current teamcity build settings to do same i.e. just analyze for errors so that it runs faster ?

regarding using the gradle plugin and to decouple it from overall migration to gradle : is it possible to create a gradle based subproject/subdirectory just for teamcity?

In https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/pull/8359 coverage build failed due to drop by 0.09% (report says coverage of files not touched in the PR dropped)
also in any case, do we really want to fail the overall build on code coverage drop of 0.09% .

@clintropolis @gianm 
while code coverage is an interesting metric , I don't think it is a metric to chase for and fail the builds.

@glasser Hi David, do you know if there is any progress on this issue? We were hoping to use this feature for a use-case but have come across this bug. Otherwise, do you know if there is an undocumented workaround?
I do not understand why the coveralls reports decreased coverage after [this](https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/pull/8304/commits/f369a927dc551ad93bc4e5de16ffd24fa597dd31) change
@himanshug I'm hoping https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/pull/8374 will fix the issue with the fluctuating coverage reports
I'm hoping #8374 will fix the issue with the fluctuating coverage reports

My attention has been elsewhere but my situation remains the same -- the fix seems trivial but I'd be way more comfortable making it if there was a more integration/end to end test showing that the fix was correct, and I need advice on how to do that.
That's weird. I don't seem to hit this issue when I run the tests locally. Let me look into it.

> is it not possible to adjust current teamcity build settings to do same i.e. just analyze for errors so that it runs faster?

You should consult JetBrains support as documented [here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/blob/master/dev/teamcity.md#contacting-teamcity-support-regarding-problems-with-builds).

I asked because you proposed that it could be done with gradle plugin and I thought you would know whether it could be done on the current build :)

anyways, thanks for the link to documentation. I read through it and discovered that most of the analysis info is stored in `.idea/inspectionProfiles/Druid.xml` which has lines like....


```
$ fgrep "<inspection_tool" .idea/inspectionProfiles/Druid.xml | head
    <inspection_tool class="Annotator" enabled="true" level="WARNING" enabled_by_default="true" />
    <inspection_tool class="AntDuplicateTargetsInspection" enabled="true" level="WARNING" enabled_by_default="true" />
    <inspection_tool class="AntMissingPropertiesFileInspection" enabled="true" level="WARNING" enabled_by_default="true" />
    <inspection_tool class="AntResolveInspection" enabled="true" level="WARNING" enabled_by_default="true" />
    <inspection_tool class="ArrayEquality" enabled="true" level="ERROR" enabled_by_default="true" />
    <inspection_tool class="ArrayEquals" enabled="true" level="ERROR" enabled_by_default="true" />
    <inspection_tool class="ArrayHashCode" enabled="true" level="ERROR" enabled_by_default="true" />
    <inspection_tool class="ArrayObjectsEquals" enabled="true" level="ERROR" enabled_by_default="true" />
    <inspection_tool class="ArraysAsListWithZeroOrOneArgument" enabled="true" level="ERROR" enabled_by_default="true" />
    <inspection_tool class="AssertWithSideEffects" enabled="true" level="ERROR" enabled_by_default="true" />
```

that suggests to me that teamcity build is applying these listed tools while analyzing the code and tagging the violations as WARNING/ERROR/... based on the "level" attribute in there.

there are 142 of these inspection tools , 90 with level ERROR and 52 with rest.
```
$ fgrep "<inspection_tool" .idea/inspectionProfiles/Druid.xml | wc -l
     142
$ fgrep "<inspection_tool" .idea/inspectionProfiles/Druid.xml | grep 'level="ERROR"' | wc -l
      90
$ fgrep "<inspection_tool" .idea/inspectionProfiles/Druid.xml | grep -v 'level="ERROR"' | wc -l
      52
```

I am gonna do a quick PR that removes all `inspection_tool` tags that don't have level ERROR and that should probably make teamcity build only analyze for ERRORs and hopefully run significantly faster as well.
Note: inspection tools could also be disabled/enabled from Intellij IDE UI (Editor -> Inspections)

```
druid.authenticator.<authenticator_name>.useForwardedHeaders
```

How difficult would it be to spoof the forwarded header? E.g., suppose a user knows the trusted domain but isn't otherwise able to send messages originating from that domain, would they be able to construct a 'X-Forwarded-For' header with an IP/hostname from the trusted domain and get authenticated that way?

I think this is a bad idea because these warnings have a purpose - engineers who use IntelliJ see them as yellow highlighting and may fix the smelly code immediately.

Also, there are a lot of warnings which are not in this XML. The XML lists just non-default settings. All inspections which are warnings by default are not listed.

Hmm, that's a good point. I think given those facts, a test of DimValHolder would be sufficient for this patch, even though it doesn't test the original bug situation. Perhaps in the future we could consider testing this class of bugs through a more powerful integration testing framework.

so , to me it seems , to have different behaviors,  we need to keep two separate xmls
one for teamcity which has stuff based on what we want to happen in teamcity build
and one for intellij IDE users for their local development
not ideal, but would work.

I still don't understand how gradle plugin would solve it though.

> @gianm @vogievetsky does Imply has any plans to implement part 2 of #6923?

I would definitely like to make it available outside of just the Router. The tricky bit is that the unified console uses Coordinator APIs, Overlord APIs, and Broker APIs. It currently runs on the Router because that is the only process type that can make all three kinds of APIs available (it proxies to them all).

I think one of the following plans makes the most sense,

1. Do it on the Coordinator, perhaps by falling back to a 'light' mode that only uses Coordinator and Overlord APIs. Not all functionality would be available. In particular, query functionality would not be available, as well as anything that relies on [system tables](https://druid.apache.org/docs/latest/querying/sql#system-schema).
2. Do it on the Broker, perhaps by folding Router functionality into the Broker (`druid.broker.asRouter = true`?). This would allow the Broker to proxy to the Coordinator and Overlord APIs.

When I think about this right now I lean to the second idea (Broker) since it promotes the idea of a single server type that you use to interact with your Druid cluster. It feels like a simpler experience for especially new users.

> Do it on the Broker, perhaps by folding Router functionality into the Broker (`druid.broker.asRouter = true`?). This would allow the Broker to proxy to the Coordinator and Overlord APIs.

This could also involve adding a management proxy to the Broker, rather than full-on Router functionality.

It may also be valuable to add the console toâ€¦Â both? I think they serve different goals.

Coordinator: serves the goal of deprecating / removing the old consoles.

Broker: serves the goal of having a single server type that you use to interact with the Druid cluster.
this patch will case young gc and old gc pressure increase.

> How did you fix this issue?

That was my first view of druid. 
You should know zookeeper is incredibly important in your cluster and all your nodes should configure correctly about this.
This is the tip.

Might be worth adding a test if this code is not covered already.
@leventov so all public static (excluding public static final ) fields should be just public?
Visibility modifier doesn't matter. static, non-final fields are a global mutable state, which is bad. Most often it's just an omission of the `final` modifier.
@leventov then what happens to non final static fields used in static blocks?

That url does not lead a file, it is just a helper page to find the nearest mirror, does that URL need to link to a specific mirror? Something like https://www-eu.apache.org/dist/incubator/druid/0.15.1-incubating/apache-druid-0.15.1-incubating-bin.tar.gz ?

Hi @Dylan1312, apologies for the delay into looking at this, could you provide some additional details about which Hadoop distribution/version and index task configuration that lead to encountering this issue? 

I don't seem to have a problem on indexing or historical side if I use the docker container we provide for the Hadoop quick-start tutorial, which admittedly is hardly a realistic test, but word on the street is that releases greater than 0.14.0 work for at least some versions of Hadoop besides the version we bundle by default (2.8.3).

I pulled your branch, and I can't quite tell what this patch would change; in terms of raw jars, a build of this branch appears identical to current master. But, I am also not incredibly familiar with the Hadoop index task class loader stuff, so maybe I'm missing something important in that regards? I'll try to have a closer look and see if I can get a better idea of what specifically is going on in there.

> Then what happens to non final static fields used in static blocks?

What do you mean? Nothing relevant to this issue happens to such fields.

Hey @clintropolis, no problem at all and thanks for looking! Happy to bump the milestone on this since we haven't heard of anyone else that's affected.

We're using a Cloudera distro of 2.6. I can get a full example of an indexing spec but I think the most pertinent thing that's potentially different is setting mapreduce.job.classloader = true (to avoid a jackson dependency conflict). Guessing that without classloader isolation the missing classes would be present in the hadoop install itself.

Example below showing the difference between a build of this branch and our latest release, note hadoop-mapreduce-client-core-2.8.3.jar isn't present within druid-hdfs-storage in the latter.

```
âžœ  ls apache-druid-0.16.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT/extensions/druid-hdfs-storage/hadoop-mapreduce*

apache-druid-0.16.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT/extensions/druid-hdfs-storage/hadoop-mapreduce-client-app-2.8.3.jar
```
